dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.text: It'll be a lot more than what you're doing sitting here and just give me lip service.  I'd like to go back at least do some aggressive searching for my stuff.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: We have plenty of aggressive searching going on it's not there.  Someone's taken it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Sure, yeah right you have plenty of aggressive searching going on, aggressive searching, drinking coffee and smoking cigarettes.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I know what you guys do when you're not working you're union people; you just sit around on your ass.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You know I don't need to take this sort of abuse.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, I don't need to take this kind of abuse either.  I just was trying get back to Atlanta. I just got home, I just want to get my bag and get my stuff. And keep my job.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That's fantastic.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Then why don't you take your fifty dollars. Get yourself a taxi and go shopping tomorrow.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: [BREATHING]

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Thank you very much.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Did you get the mail? So you saw my letter?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's not fair.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah.  I know.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't understand.  You've already done so much, I don't know why do you have to go back.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't know.  I put in that. request too. They didn't...

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I guess, you know, everybody has to make sacrifices.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know, it's just not fair.  I think you've already made your sacrifice.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: There's people that have given more though, you know?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I just don't see how they can make you leave when you have a new baby - we have a new kid.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I know.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Then why is that fair?  Why--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: There's babies over there, though, that need mothers.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know how you can be okay with this?  I don't know why you're not-- you're fine with it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm not okay with it, but I don't-- it's not like I have a choice.  I don't see what crying about it is going to fix.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm just trying to think of another way.  I'm just trying to...

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Just, you know, kicking myself.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: like you sign up because you need money and

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: things just aren't what they seem.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: This is a stupid war.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: We're doing the right thing, though.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I know.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I just don't see why it has to be you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: If not me then, who?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What am I going to do? Huh?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You'll videotape everything, yeah?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Maybe you can send it to me, like stream it, yeah?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Don't you guys have access to computers over there.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Last month--  Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I just don't know how I'm going to do it without you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I have to find sitters.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I can't raise a baby by myself.  How?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: We've got friends, that's why we moved here, huh?  Because there is a day care down the street.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: And your mother is close by.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'll send you lots of letters.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: And I want lots and lots and lots of pictures.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's just not fair.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What time is it?  I think it's supposed to run around midnight, right?  God, this is great, isn't it, Carla?  Look at this night we got here, huh.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Actually I want to get a little further up the coast, get away from all like the lights and the people, but...  How are you doing?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Fine.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay.  Is that, is that--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No.  That's just foam.  I don't know.  I can't tell.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: [BREATHING]

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know, probably if you can't tell, though, it's probably not them, right?  It's probably going to be like this unmistakable thing, right?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh no.  you know what I forgot?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: My flashlight.  God, how could I be so stupid?  I can't believe I forgot my flashlight.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What flashlight?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: The flashlight, the silver one.  There's only one, isn't there?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That's not your flashlight.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Whose is it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's ours; it's my flashlight too.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh...well. Yeah, of course.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You keep saying my flashlight like it's just yours.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: How's that supposed to make me feel?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Of course, our flashlight.  What's yours is mine.  Me flashlight es su flashlight.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Naturally.  God, how could we not think to bring it?  I hope the moon stays out, though.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Do they always run during a full moon?  I don't remember.  Was it full last year?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Huh.  Are you cold?  Do you want my jacket?  No?  you know, we should have brought the blanket?  Our blanket.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Aw.  Do you know, I should have brought a six pack, too.  A six pack, that would be just the ticket right about now.  Huh?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: God, I'm so excited, I'm like a kid.  I can't believe I got out of the house with my fly zipped up.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: [LAUGHTER]

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I wonder if they can hear me talk or like feel the vibrations in the sand when we move around.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm cold.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Do you want my jacket?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's after eleven, let's go.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What?  We just got here.  What's the point of coming all the way down here if we just turn around and go home?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: There is no point.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Right.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That's my point.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Wait, that's my point, too.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, then let's go.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, no.  Okay.  That's not my point.  My point is there is no point in coming down here if we just turn around and go home.  Don't you want to see it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Not particularly.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why not?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I just don't.  It's stupid.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Honey, this is like a natural phenomenon. I mean... People in Kansas would have to get plane reservations and get hotel rooms to see this.  It's just forty minutes away for us; it's too good to pass up.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Pass what up?  I mean these fish swim out of the ocean, they flop around on the beach, they swim away and then they die.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah.  But this..this moment on the beach is like the highlight of their little lives.  All that flopping around is laying eggs or what to do - spawning or mating or whatever.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: This is a big night for these little guys.  It's like life's last orgy.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't see why you're so excited; this isn't a freaking moon landing we are talking about.  It's fish.  It's a fish nobody even eats.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah they do.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh Augie

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: okay... well, Whatever.  But it's a fish who do something no other fish do.  It's like those swallows returning to Capistrano or like those lemmings that throw themselves off the cliffs.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: There's like mystery here, there's magic.  It's like a little bit of the unexplainable.  I just can't see how you're not interested.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm just not.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: For real?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: God, I don't get it.  you know the first time we came here, you said it was the best night of your life?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And last year, I remember distinctly you said, you were so excited to get here that you don't remember you stubbed your toe until we were in the car.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Last time, you'll also remember, we got our shoes wet, I got sand in my panties, you got a sore throat and we got into a big fight and we did not see the grunions.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Ahh...we weren't in a good spot.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Hmm.  We didn't see them the year before either.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We just weren't in a good spot.  I'm telling you, this is a much better spot.  I have instincts for these things.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Look there, see?  What's that?  No, that's - that's just seaweed.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: God, this is great.  Think about this.  I know you are not interested, but just think about this.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Right now out there, there is this mass of silver fish and it's heading this way.  No one sent them an invitation, no one told them, no one even gave them a map.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Just all at once, they turned and they formed this line as long as the California coast.  And some instinctual little firecracker went off in their bodies and they all just turned as one and started swimming.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: They are swimming right now.  They are swimming as if that is the only thing that matters to them.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's single mindedness with no mind.  It is urgency that is just pure urge.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And they are swimming right now to this very point where we stand for this huge celebration of sex and death.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh look.  I'm giving myself goose bumps, my hairs are standing up on my arm.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That's the wind.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So what do you think?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: About what?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: About all of that, about all I was talking about.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What's going on?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Kathy died last night.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh my God. Oh my God, I'm so sorry.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: yeah, I mean, you know, it was a -

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I guess we saw it coming and she lasted a lot - a lot longer than, uh, they expected but you know, I mean when it actually happens it's just a lot harder.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It doesn't make any easier, yes.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I mean at least she was home, she wasn't in the hospital anymore,

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh, man. I'm so sorry.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: She was with- yeah  She was with Gary, and he said that she was just sitting there and went to sleep, closed her eyes, and that was it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's going to be so rough, I'm sorry.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes. I mean, it's not as rough on me as it is on him but

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: God, it's you know, we've spent so much time with them it's just really surreal, really weird that we're not going to be able to see her anymore and go

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: out to- out to dinner you know and do the troops to California, I mean.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Totally.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's just that- I don't know, it's sort it's sort- of a weird thing you know

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: not being able to see anyone again, who knows where they really went, you know. I mean, I guess we can just hope that wherever they are now if it's anywhere that it's better I mean.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yes. Well, at least you have a lot of good memories.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: She was [garbage]

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: She really cared about you, you know.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes, I mean she cared about all of us. She was great

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: so loving everybody you know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: And she was

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Gosh, I just hate I just hate to see her go.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We were all going take a trip to Europe you know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Even if you still do she'll- she'll be there.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes.  [BREATHING] God.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Are you going to be okay?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I just -- I just don't get it, like there is just nothing you can do about it you know, it's like just out of your control and it

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: just makes it that much harder to deal 'cause as much as you want to, you know, make her better, see her not in any pain, it's like, just I don't know, just has a mind of its own.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Then she's gone.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's going to be okay, I promise.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, you know I appreciate you coming over and talking to me, I mean it definitely helps

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Sure

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: to talk to somebody but

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: you shouldn't be alone

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's just going to take a while, I think.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yes.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Ah.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Thank you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yes.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Good God.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Do you think it's them?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I wonder.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, nobody knows we're here except Freda and she wouldn't ring up.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Must be them then.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What are we going to do?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We're all right darling, aren't we whatever happens?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Now and always sweet.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't care then.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's bound to come sooner or later.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Hello? Hello? What? Wrong number.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh. It sends shivers down my spine.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What do we do if they suddenly walk in on us?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Behave exquisitely.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: With the most perfect poise.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yes, I should probably to a court curtsey.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Things that ought to matter dreadfully don't matter at all when one's is happy, do they?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What's so horrible is that one can't stay happy.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh darling don't say that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's true; the whole business is a very poor joke.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Meaning that sacred and beautiful thing love?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yes. Meaning just that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What does it all mean that's what I ask- that's what I ask myself in my ceaseless quest for ultimate truth?  Good God what does it all mean?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Don't laugh at me. I'm serious.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You mustn't be serious my dear one, that's just what they want.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Who's they?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: All those futile moralists, who try to make life unbearable, laugh at them, be flippant. Laugh at everything all their sacred shibboleths

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: flippancy brings out the acid in their damned sweetness in light.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, if I laugh at everything then I must laugh at us too.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Certainly you must, we figures of fun all right.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, shall we always want to bicker and fight?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, that desire will fade along with our passion.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh dear, should we like that?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Depends on how well we play it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, what happens if one of us dies, does the one that's left still laugh?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes, yes, with all his might.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well that's serious enough, isn't it?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, no it isn't, death is very laughable, such a cunning little mystery, all done with mirrors.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Darling, I believe you're talking nonsense.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So is everyone else in the long run.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Let's be superficial and pity the poor philosophers, let's blow our trumpets and squeakers and enjoy the party as much as we can. Like quite idiotic, very small, school children. Let's savor the delight of the moment.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Come kiss me darling before your body rots and worms pop in and out of your eye sockets.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Elliot, worms don't pop.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't care what you do see. You can paint yourself green and dance naked in the Place Vendome, and rush off madly with all the men in the world and I shan't say a word, as long as you love me best.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Thank you dear, the same applies you, except that if I catch you so much as looking at another woman, I'll kill you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You remember that awful scene we had in Venice?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Which particular one?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: The one when you bought that little, painted, wooden snake in the Piazza and put it on my bed.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh Charles, that was his name Charles. It did wiggle so beautifully.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Horrible thing, I hated it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I know you did. You threw it out of the window into the Grand Canal; I don't think I'll ever forgive you for that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: How long did that row last?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It went on intermittently for days.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: The worst one was in Cannes when your curling iron burned a hole in my new dressing gown.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It burned my comb too and all the towels in the bathroom.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: That was a rouser, wasn't it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That was the first time you ever hit me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I didn't hit you very hard.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: The manager came in and found us rolling around on the floor biting and scratching like panthers.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'll never forget his face.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh it was ridiculous, completely ridiculous.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We were very much younger then.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: And very much sillier.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: As a matter of fact the real cause of that row was Peter Burden.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes.  The real cause of that rile was Peter Burden.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh, come on, you knew there was nothing in that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I knew nothing of the sort.  You took presents from him.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Presents?  A trivial little broach.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Mmm Hmm.  I remember it well.  Bristling with diamonds in the worst possible taste.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Not at all.  It was very pretty.  I still have it and I wear it often.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You went out of your way to torture me over Peter Burden.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No I didn't.  You made up the whole thing in your jealous imagination.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You must admit he was in love with you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Just a little perhaps but nothing serious.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You let him kiss you. You said so.  What of it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well what of it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well it didn't harm him, in fact, it pleasured him a lot and it didn't hurt me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And what about me?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, if you hadn't been so suspicious and nosey you would've never known anything.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh, that's a nice point of view I must say.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Look, I'm bored with this conversation.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah, so am I.  Bored stiff.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You want some brandy?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No thanks.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'll have a little I think.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't know why you want it.  You've already had two glasses.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No particular reason.  Anyhow they were very small ones.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't see what you have to go on and on with this kind of thing.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh my...just because I just...okay...

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: ...having three small minute liquor glasses in the evening is hardly going on and on and on.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's become a habit with you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You needn't be so grand just because you don't happen to want any yourself at the moment.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Don't be so stupid.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Really Amanda.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Nothing.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: [BREATHING]

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Going out somewhere dear?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No, just making myself beautiful for you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: That reply has broken my heart.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That's the woman's job to lure the man.  Watch me a moment won't you?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Actually that's perfectly true.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No it isn't.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes it is.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh, be quiet.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I think you should have some more brandy...

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I think that

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: ...cause really

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: it doesn't seem to be working on you.

dialogue.speaker: M

dialogue.text: You're the only one I know that still loves his parents.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah. I know. It went out of style, didn't it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No, it's all right. There's nothing wrong in that, you know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's really lovely here. The air is sweet.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You're not sorry you came?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No. I'm not sorry. It's-

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I can't stay.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why not?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, for one thing, your mother so much has told me to go. [LAUGHTER].

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well-

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Look,

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: you've been acting kind of, well, you know.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, you've been embarrassed ever since I came.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes, I guess I have been. But it's going from me now.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh look, um, well, the thing is, I was planning on, planning on sort of sneaking up on you over a week or so, and they-they take it for granted we're all set.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: How did you know?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah, they would. Especially your mom.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, uh- would you want to?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I, I guess that's why I asked you to come.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, I mean,

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh, Annie.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: from her opinion, why else would I come here?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Annie, I love you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I love you a great deal.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I-I love you. I have no imagination. That's all I know how to tell it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, I guess that's why I came.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm embarrassing you. I didn't want to tell you it here. I wanted to go somewhere that would be brand-new to each other. It feels wrong here, don't you? This yard and this chair.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't want to win you from anybody. I want you to be ready for me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I've been ready for a long, long time.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Then he's gone forever. You're sure?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Look

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I was almost married two years ago.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why didn't you?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: 'Cause you started to write me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You felt something that far back?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Every day since.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why didn't you let me know?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, I don't know, you didn't write until then and then when you did, what'd you say?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You always can be so ambiguous.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Give me a kiss, Annie.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Give me-

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: [LAUGHTER]. God, I kissed Annie. I kissed Annie. How long, how long I've been waiting to kiss you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't know if I ever can forgive you for that. Why'd you wait so long? I sat in my room wondering if I was crazy for thinking about you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We're going to live now. I'm going to make you so happy.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Not like that, you're not.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I kissed you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Like Larry's brother. Do it like you, Chris.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What is it?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Let's drive somewhere. I want to be alone with you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No. What is it? Is it your mother?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, no, no, no. Nothing like that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well then tell me what's wrong. I mean, even in your letters there's something ashamed.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah. I guess there is. I guess I was, but uh- it's going from me now.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You should tell me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know where to start.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: But, Chris, it wouldn't work like this.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know when I went overseas. I said I was in command of a company.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah, sure.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, I lost them.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: How many?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Just about all.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Geez.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It takes a little while to toss that off. Because they weren't just men.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: For instance, one time, it had to have been raining several days. There was this one kid, he came up to me and he gave me his last pair of dry socks. Put them in my pocket.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I mean, that's-that's only a little thing, but that's the kind of guys I had. They didn't just die. They killed themselves for each other. And I mean that exactly. A little more selfish and they'd still be here today.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And I, and I thought something watching them go down.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Everything was being destroyed, see, but there was one new thing that was being created. A kind of responsibility, man for man. You understand me?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And to show that-to bring that onto the earth like some sort of monument standing right behind us where everyone could feel it and it would make a difference to him.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And I came back here and it was incredible. There was no meaning in that here. The whole thing to them was a bus accident.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And I went to work with dad and that rat race again. And I felt what you said-ashamed somehow. Because nobody was changed at all. It seemed to make a sucker out of a lot of guys.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And I felt wrong to be alive. To drive the car, to see the new checkbook, to see the new refrigerator. I mean, you can take those things out of the war. But you got to know that when you drive that car that that came out of the love a man can have for another man. And you got to be a little bit better because of that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Otherwise, what you have here is loot; and there's blood on it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And I didn't want to take any of it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And I guess that included you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: And you still feel that way?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I want you now, Annie.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Because you can't feel that way, never again, Chris. You hear me? Never. I mean, the money and me too.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I mean, there's nothing wrong in that money, and your father put good planes up in the air and you should be proud of that. A man should be paid for that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Annie,

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Annie, I'm going to make a fortune for you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What am I going to do with a fortune?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't know, Brian, if they uh--it's been three years.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Hey, you just got to keep on going.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No, I don't know, I--maybe this isn't for me. You know, maybe this isn't the right business for me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, don't think like that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I just, I see all these other people getting commercials and work and it's like I'm not getting anything.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I have no money behind me. Nothing. I'm twenty five and--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Russel Crowe wasn't forty until he got his big stuff.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: If you really want to do it-I mean,

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: So I'll have to wait twenty five years-

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: you got to do.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: -just going and auditioning and auditioning and rejection after refection, it's like--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You could. You could. We just--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: we're just pooling our funds together.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I know, I just don't know if I can handle it. I mean, you're helping me so much financially it's like I can't survive on my own without you. I don't like that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You don't owe me anything.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I feel like I'm not doing anything. Like I'm not giving anything into this world.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You are, you're going to class, you're learning, you're getting better. When you finally get that role you're going to be prepared.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah, but what if I never make it? What if I studied all my life, this theatre, this acting, and I'm never going to get anywhere. I'm never going to be able to have a job.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh my God, Anna, you're still young. Don't even think about that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Time is passing by. Every year it's

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: a part left than I can do.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You're only twenty five, okay? Some people don't start until they're thirty five.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Really?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't know, I just [BREATHING] I get frustrated

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What would you do- What would you do if you didn't? You can go to law school.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That's the thing. I don't know. I don't know anything.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Law school? Maybe.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't know. I don't know anything other than this, though, is the problem. This is my life. This is what I built everything about, you know.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: See? So you can't just quit now.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I mean, I could go to law school, but I'm just not passionate about it, you know? Like I'm not--it doesn't drive me, it doesn't motivate me. I--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Have you been going to auditions and stuff?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah. I mean, I get a call-back and stuff, but-

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I just, I need a break. I need something to break me out.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: How's the job? Still waiting tables at Denny's?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah. Unfortunately.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah, so I go to--get an education for four years and I'm waiting tables at Denny's.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, they tip well.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: [BREATHING] Brian-

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: it's not funny. I just don't know what I'm going to do.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Maybe you could start teaching. I don't know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah, I guess I could.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Go back to school. You know? Another three more years, get your master's.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Close to thirty. Oof, it's going to be tough.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Thanks.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: [LAUGHTER]

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: [BREATHING]

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What's he going to say?  Maybe we ought to tell him before he sees it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: He saw it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: How could he see it?  I was the first one up.  He was still in bed.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: He was out here when it broke.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: When?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: About four this morning.  I heard it cracking and I woke up and looked out.  He was standing right there when it cracked.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What was he doing out here at four in the morning?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know.  After it cracked, he ran back in the house and cried in the kitchen.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Did you talk to him?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No.  I - I figured the best thing was to leave him alone.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: He cried hard?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I heard him right through the floor of my room.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What was he doing out here at that hour?  He's dreaming about him again.  He's walking around at night.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I guess he is.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: He's getting just like after he died.  What's the meaning in that?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know the meaning of it, mom.  But I know one thing; we made a terrible mistake with dad.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Being dishonest with him.  That kind of thing always pays off and now it's paying off.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What do you mean, dishonest?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know that Larry's not coming back.  And I know it.  Why do we allow him to go on thinking that we believe with him?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What do you want to do?  Argue with him?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't want to argue with him but it's time he realized that nobody believes Larry's alive anymore.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why shouldn't he dream of him?  Walk the nights waiting for him.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Do we contradict him?  Do we say straight out that we have no hope anymore?  That we haven't had any hope for years, now.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You can't say that to him.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We've gotta say it to him.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: How are you going to prove it?  Can you prove it?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: For God's sake, three years.  Nobody comes back after three years.  It's insane.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: To you it is and to me, but not to him.  You can talk yourself blue in the face, but there's no body and no grave, so where are you?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Sit down, mom.  I want to talk to you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: The trouble is the Goddamn newspapers.  Every month some boy turns up from nowhere, so the next boy is going to be Larry.  So we have to keep--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Alright, alright, alright.  Listen.  You know why I asked Annie here don't you?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Why?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know why.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well I've got an idea, but what's the story?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Going to ask her to marry me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well that's only your business, Chris.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know it's not only my business.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What do you want me to do?  You're old enough to know your own mind.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Then it's alright.  I'll go ahead with it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well you want to make sure your father isn't going to have --

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, then you know it's not only my business.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm just saying.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Sometimes you infuriate me, you know that?  Isn't it your business, too, if I tell this to father and he throws a fit about it?  You have such a talent for ignoring things.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I ignore what I got to ignore.  The girl is Larry's girl.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: She's not Larry's girl.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: From father's point of view, he's not dead.  And you have no right to take his girl.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Now you can go on from there if you know where to go. But I'm telling you I don't know where to go.  See, I don't know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Now what can I do for you?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know why it is but every time I reach out for something I want, I have to pull back because other people will suffer.  My whole bloody life, time after time after time.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You're a considerate fellow.  There's nothing wrong in that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: To hell with that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Did you ask Annie yet?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I wanted to get this settled first.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: How do you know she'll marry you?  Maybe she feels the same way father does.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well if she does, then that's the end of it.  From her letters, I think she's forgotten him.  We'll find out.  Then we'll thrash it out with dad. Right, mom?  Don't avoid me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: The trouble is, you don't see enough women.  You never did.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So what?  I'm not fast with women.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't see why it has to be Annie.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Because it is.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well that's a good answer, but it don't answer anything.  He thinks he's coming back, Chris.  You marry that girl, you're pronouncing him dead.  Now what happens to your father?  Do you know?  Because I don't.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Line?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Alright, then, mom.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Alright, then, mom.  Did we skip something?  No.  Alright, then, mom.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yes we did. Do you want to keep going?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah, let's keep going.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Just give it some more thought.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I've given it three years' of thought.  I'd hope that if

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: father forgot about Larry, we'd have a regular wedding and everything happy.  If I can't get that here, then I'll have to get out.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What the hell is this?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'll get out.  I'll get married and live someplace else.  Maybe New York.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Are you crazy?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I've been a good son too long; a good sucker.  I'm through with it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You've got a business here.  What the hell is this?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: The business?  The business doesn't inspire me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Must you be inspired?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes.  I like getting an hour a day.  If I have to grub for money all day long, at least at evening, I want it beautiful.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I want a family.  I want some kids.  I want to build something I can give myself to.  Annie's in the middle of that.  Now where do I find it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You mean -- tell me something.  You mean you'd really leave the business?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes, on this I would.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You don't want to think like that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Then you help me stay here.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Alright.  But just don't think like that because what the hell did we work for?  That's all for you, Chris.  The whole shooting match is just for you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I know that.  Just you help me stay here.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: But don't think that way, you hear me?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I am thinking that way.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't understand you, do I?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, you don't.  I'm a pretty tough guy.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah, I can see that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: That was a rouser, wasn't it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That was the first time you ever hit me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I didn't hit you very hard.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: The manager came in and found us rolling about on the floor, biting and scratching like panthers.  Oh, dear.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I shall never forget his face.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: How ridiculous.  How utterly, utterly ridiculous.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We were very much younger then.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: And very much sillier.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: As a matter of fact, the real cause of that row was Peter Burden.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You knew there was nothing in that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I knew nothing of the sort.  You took presents from him.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Presents?  A trivial little brooch.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I remember it well, bristling with diamonds in the worst possible taste.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Not at all.  It was very pretty.  I still have it and I wear it often.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You went out of your way to torture me over Peter Burden.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I did not.  You made the whole thing up in your jealous imagination.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You must admit that he was in love with you, wasn't he?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Just a little, perhaps, nothing serious.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Line?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Let him kiss you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You let him kiss you.  You said you did.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What of it?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What of it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It gave him a lot of pleasure and it didn't hurt me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What about me?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: If you hadn't been so nosey, you never would have known a thing about it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: That's a nice point of view, I must say.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh, dear.  I'm bored with this conversation.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So am I; bored stiff.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You want some brandy?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No, thanks.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'll have a little myself, I think.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't see why you want it.  You've already had two glasses.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No particular reason.  Anyhow, they were very small ones.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It seems so silly to go on and on and on with such a thing.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You can hardly call three liquor glasses in a whole evening going on and on and on.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's become a habit with you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You needn't be so grand just because you don't happen to want any at the moment.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh, don't be so stupid.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Really, Amanda

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Nothing.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Going out somewhere, my dear?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No, just making myself fascinating for you

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh.  That reply has broken my heart.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: The woman's job is to allure the man.  Watch me a minute, will you?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: As a matter of fact, that's perfectly true.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh, no, it isn't.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes, it is.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh, be quiet.

dialogue.speaker: M

dialogue.text: to open that bank book; to drive the new car; to see the new refrigerator.  I mean, you can take these things out of a war, but when you drive the new car, you have to know that it came out of the love a man can have for a man.

dialogue.text: You have to be a little better because of that.  Otherwise, we have is really loot and there's blood on it.  I don't want to take any of it.  I guess that included you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: And do you still feel that way?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I want you now, Annie.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Because you mustn't feel that way anymore, Chris.  Because you have a right to everything you have, everything, Chris; to me, too.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: And your money, there's nothing wrong in your money.  Your father put hundreds of planes in the air.  You should be proud.  A man should be paid for that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Annie, Annie, I'm going to make you a fortune.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What'll I do with a fortune?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Hey, how you doing?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm sorry.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Thanks.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I know- I know there's nothing I can say that will really help, but--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I know.  I just -- I don't know.  It's just weird because you have somebody who's, you know,

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: a major part of your life and then they're gone.  And I don't know.  That's not really -- it's never really happened to me before.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm sorry.  It's never easy.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: But, I'm here if there's anything you need.  I mean, you just have to ask.  I know --

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Thanks.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: --it doesn't really do anything.  But--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I just -- it's just not fair.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I know.  It never is.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: How's, um -- how's his parents doing?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I mean, they're, you know, they're upset.  It's like you know, they

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: feel the same way everybody else does.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I mean, what do you want to do?  Do you want to- do you want to talk about it?  Do you-

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: [BREATHING] I mean, there's nothing really to talk about.  He's gone and I'll never see him again.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well I know it's not a lot of help or anything, but at least you got to know him.  I mean, at least you had the time with him that you did.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I mean, we can be grateful for that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah, I don't know.  Sometimes I wish I didn't know him.  So I wouldn't--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You feel that way now because you're upset.  But you don't really think that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It'll get better.  I know it doesn't help, but it will get better and you will remember all of the good things that you guys had; all of the memories that you have with him that were happy and you'll be grateful for those.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: This is just -- this is a terrible life.  I just don't understand.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Just life, in general?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I mean, it's just not fair.  Like, I don't know.  Why people -

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: there should just be some sort of rule that people don't die until they're older, 'cause then, at least, it's expected.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I agree.  If I knew how to make that happen, I would certainly help you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know what to do.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: When's the service? Can- can we help?  Is there anything, I mean--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I mean, you- you can go.  I don't know.  I don't know what else.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I hope it rains.  Somehow that'll make me feel more comfortable.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Seems like if the whole world's sad, then it's okay for you to be.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I just wish there was some way to just bring him back to life magically.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I know.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Just, you know, some thing; some genie. I need to find a genie bottle.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't have any magic answers.  But,

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I mean, as- as cliche as it is, as long as people who loved him remember him, then it's not a waste, you know.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I know.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh Good God.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Do you think it's them?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I wonder.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: what, Nobody knows we are here except Freda and she wouldn't ring up.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Must be them then?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What do we do?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We're all right, aren't we, darling, whatever happens?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Now and always, my sweet.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't care then.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It was bound to happen sooner or later.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Hello?  Hello?  What?  Wrong number.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh, it sent shivers up my spine.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh, what shall we do if they suddenly walk in on us.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Behave exquisitely.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: With the worst- with the most perfect poise?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I shall probably do a Court Curtsey.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Uhh, It's amazing how once you feel--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: things that ought to matter most dreadfully don't matter at all when one's happy, do they?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What's so horrible is that one can't stay happy.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Uhh, You mustn't say that, my darling.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, it's true.  The whole business is a very poor joke.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Being that sacred and wonderful thing, love.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Meaning just that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Um What does it all mean?  That's what I ask myself in my endless quest for ultimate truth.  Dear God, what does it all mean?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Don't laugh at me.  I'm serious.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You mustn't be serious, darling.  That's just what they want.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Who's they?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: All the futile mortals who try to make life unbearable.  Laugh at them, Be flippant.  Laugh at everything, all their sacred shibboleths.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: uh- the- Being flippant brings out the acid in their damned beauty and light.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: If I laugh at everything, then I must laugh at us too.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Certainly you must.  We are figures of fun all right.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh, how long will it last, this ludicrous, overbearing love of ours?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: [garbage] who knows?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, will we always bicker and fight?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No.  That fire will fade along with our passion.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh, dear.  Shall we like that?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, it depends on how well we played.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What if one of us dies, does the other one laugh then?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes, yes, with all his might.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That's rather serious, isn't it?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, no that is quit laughable.  The cutting little mystery all done with mirrors.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Darling, I do believe you're talking nonsense.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So is everyone else in the long run.  Let's be superficial and pity the poor philosophers.  Let's blow trumpets and squeakers and enjoy the party as long as we can, like little quiet idiotic school children.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: [garbage] Darling, kiss me before your body rots and worms start popping in and out of your eye sockets.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Elliott, worms don't pop.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't care what you do.  See, you could paint your body bright green and and run naked through the Place Vendome and run with every man in the world and I shan't say a word.  As long as I know that you love me best.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Uhh, Thank you, darling.  And the same goes for you, except that if I ever see you so much as look at another woman, I'll kill you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Do you remember that awful scene we had in Venice?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Which particular one?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: The one where you bought that little painted wooden stake and you put it on my bed.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Awe, Charles.  That was his name.  He did wriggle so beautifully.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Horrible thing.  I hated it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I know you did.  You threw it out the window into the Canal below.  I don't think I'll ever forgive you for that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: How long did that roue last?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It went on intermittently for days.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh, The worst one was in Cannes when your curling iron burnt a hole in my new dressing gown?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh, It burnt my comb and all the towels in the bathroom.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: [LAUGHTER] That was quit a rouser, wasn't it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That was the first time you hit me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh, I didn't hit you very hard.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: And then the manager came in and saw us all rolling all over the floor, biting and scratching one another. [LAUGHTER]

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I should never forget his face. [LAUGHTER]

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: How ridiculous, utterly ridiculous

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We were very much younger then.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Very much sillier.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Come to think of it, the real cause of that roues was Peter Burden.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You knew there was nothing in that.
